questions.text: What is the correct sequence in Gram staining?
questions.solution:
• Primary stain: crystal violet (or gentian violet or methyl violet) for 1 minute.
  • Mordant: Gram's iodine for 1 minute.
  • Decolorization: acetone (for 1-2 sec) or ethanol (20-30 sec) with immediate wash. Decolorizer removes the primary stain from Gram-negative bacteria due to loss of lipid layer of cell wall while the Gram-positive bacteria retain the primary stain.
  • Counter stain or Secondary stain: safranin or diluted carbol fuchsin for 30-60 sec.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, Pg 13-14

questions.text: Which of the following organisms does NOT have polysaccharide capsule?
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis have protein capsules made up of polymers of d-glutamic acid(Polyglutamate capsule).

Chemical Composition of bacterial capsule:

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, Pg 20

questions.text: A researcher wish to study the effect of an antimicrobial that inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis of bacteria. In which phase of the growth curve should he observe the maximum effect of the antimicrobial?
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of peptidoglycan synthesis (e.g., beta-lactams) are most effective during the exponential phase because this is when bacteria are actively growing and dividing, requiring cell wall synthesis. Other phases like the lag, stationary, or death phases have minimal cell wall activity, reducing the drug's effectiveness.

Thus, the maximum effect is seen in the exponential phase.


  • Lag phase:
    • Vigorous metabolic activity occurs but cells do not divide
    • Few minutes up to many hours
  • Log (logarithmic/Exponential) phase
    • Rapid cell division occurs
    • Lactam drugs act during this phase when cells are making peptidoglycan 3
  • Stationary phase
    • Nutrient depletion or toxic products
    • growth slows till number of new cells produced = the number of cells that die
  • Death phase
    • Decline in the number of viable bacteria

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 2, Pg 23-25

questions.text: Best disinfectant for the equipment shown in image is:
questions.solution:
• Glutaraldehyde is used as a cold sterilant to disinfect and clean heat-sensitive equipment such as dialysis instruments, surgical instruments, suction bottles, bronchoscopes, endoscopes, and ear, nose, and throat instruments.
    • The strength of glutaraldehyde and water solutions typically ranges from 1% to 50%
    • When 2% glutaraldehyde for 10-20 min is used for manual and automated disinfection

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, Pg 133

questions.text: Virus mediated transfer of bacterial DNA from one cell to another is known is:
questions.solution:
• Transduction is defined as transmission of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage (virus infecting bacteria).
  • Transformation is the process of random uptake of free or naked DNA fragment from environment by a bacterial cell and incorporation into its chromosome in a heritable form.
  • Transcription is the process of formation of m-RNA from DNA.
  • Integration is the process of incorporation of DNA segment into chromosomal DNA.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 7, Pg 59-60

questions.text: Which technique is used in molecular biology research to study gene expression by detection of RNA in a sample?
questions.solution:
The northern blot, or RNA blot, is a technique used in molecular biology research to study gene expression by detection of RNA (or isolated mRNA) in a sample.

  • A Southern blot is a method used in molecular biology for detection of a specific DNA sequence in DNA samples. Southern blotting combines transfer of electrophoresis-separated DNA fragments to a filter membrane and subsequent fragment detection by probe hybridization
  • The far-western blot, or far-western blotting, is a molecular biological method based on the technique of western blot to detect protein-protein interaction in vitro. Whereas western blot uses an antibody probe to detect a protein of interest, far-western blot uses a non-antibody probe which can bind the protein of interest. Thus, whereas western blotting is used for the detection of certain proteins, far-western blotting is employed to detect protein/protein interactions.
  • The northwestern blot, also known as the northwestern assay, is a hybrid analytical technique of the western blot and the northern blot, and is used in molecular biology to detect interactions between RNA and proteins.
  • The eastern blot, or eastern blotting, is a biochemical technique used to analyze protein post-translational modifications including the addition of lipids, phosphates, and glycoconjugates. It is most often used to detect carbohydrate epitopes. Thus, eastern blot can be considered an extension of the biochemical technique of western blot.
  • The far-eastern blot, or far-eastern blotting, is a technique for the analysis of lipids separated by high-performance thin layer chromatography (HPTLC).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 7, Pg 66-69

questions.text: All of the following bacteria test 'Urease positive' EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Proteus, Klebsiella and Staphylococcus aureus are Urease positive.
  • E.coli are urease negative.
  • Urea Agar was developed by Christensen in 1946 for the differentiation of enteric bacilli. The urease test is used to determine the ability of an organism to split urea, through the production of the enzyme urease.
  • Principle of Urease Test : Urea is the product of decarboxylation of amino acids. Hydrolysis of urea produces ammonia and CO2. The formation of ammonia alkalinizes the medium, and the pH shift is detected by the color change of phenol red from light orange at pH 6.8 to magenta (pink) at pH 8.1. Rapid urease-positive organisms turn the entire medium pink within 24 hours. Weakly positive organisms may take several days, and negative organisms produce no color change or yellow as a result of acid production.
  • Positive Reaction: Development of an intense magenta to bright pink color in 15 min to 24h.
    • Examples: Proteus spp, Cryptococcus spp, Corynebacterium spp, Helicobacter pylori, Yersinia spp, Brucella spp, etc.
  • Negative Reaction: No color change.
    • Examples: Escherichia, Shigella, Salmonella, etc.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg 33

questions.text: Culture medium shown in the image is an example of:
questions.solution:
• MacConkey agar is an example differential medium.
  • It differentiates organisms into LF-lactose fermenters (pink colonies), e.g. E. coli and Klebsiella) and LNF-Lactose non-fermenters) (colorless colonies), e.g. Shigella and Salmonella.
  • It is also an example of selective medium as the bile salts in the medium inhibits growth of gram positive bacteria and allow only growth of gram negative bacteria.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg 29

questions.text: Which leukotriene is the adhesion factor for the neutrophil on the cell surface to attach to endothelium:
questions.solution:
• LTB 4 have a chemotactic effect on migrating neutrophils, and as such help to bring the necessary cells to the tissue.
  • The leukotrienes (e.g., LTB4) and PAF can also activate rolling leukocytes, increase the expression/avidity of CD11/CD18 and initiate the transition to firm adhesion.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 14, Pg 131-133

questions.text: A young girl brought to emergency department with sudden onset of rash. After history taking and evaluation the physician diagnosed it as Atopic Eczema. Atopy is mediated by:
questions.solution:
• Atopy refers to the genetic tendency to develop allergic diseases such as allergic rhinitis, asthma and atopic dermatitis (eczema). Atopy is typically associated with heightened immune responses to common allergens, especially inhaled allergens and food allergens.
  • Atopy is an exaggerated IgE-mediated immune response; all atopic disorders are type I hypersensitivity disorders.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12 th edition Chapter 13, Pg 200

questions.text:
A 7-year-old female with a known allergy to peanuts inadvertently ingests an ice cream containing traces of peanuts. Within one hour, she develops diffuse erythema (redness of the skin) and urticaria associated with respiratory symptoms of shortness of breath and diffuse wheezing. Recovered from this event, the next day, she went to play with a friend. The friend gave her a Japanese lacquered box as a gift.

48 hours later, she developed itchiness and redness in hands with clear fluid vesicles on her right forearm. These findings suggest which type of hypersensitivity?
questions.solution:
• Urushiol is common to poison ivy and poison oak.
  • It is a component of Japanese lacquer.
  • The urticaria (itchiness) and fluid vesicles on her forearm are hallmarks of contact dermatitis, a type IV hypersensitivity mediated by CD4+ T cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 16, Pg 164-168

choices.text: Formation of the membrane attack complex
IFN-γ secretion by CD4+ T cells
T cell precursor migration to the thymus

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial infections. Genetic testing shows an X-linked mutation affecting a tyrosine kinase involved in B-cell development. Which immune function is most likely impaired in this child?
questions.solution:
• Bruton's agammaglobulinemia results in a near or total absence of B cells and immunoglobulins; hence antibody-mediated responses to microbes are severely impaired.
  • Even without antibodies and the classical pathway of complement activation, the membrane attack complex (MAC) can be formed through the MBL and alternative pathways.
  • Antibodies are not involved in the other options.

Bruton disease (X-linked agammaglobulinemia)

  • It is characterized by failure of pre-B-cells to differentiate into immature B-cells in the bone marrow- due to absence of an enzyme called Bruton's tyrosine kinase leading to total absence of B-cells, plasma cells and all classes of Ig.
  • The B-cell maturation stops at pre B cell stage; after the synthesis of heavy-chain without forming the light chains.
  • Hence the cytoplasm of pre B cell have incomplete immunoglobulins.
  • X linked disorder: hence seen primarily in males; rarely in females.
  • Onset -after 6 months of life.
  • Secondary infection:
    • Recurrent bacterial infections,
    • Viruses (enteroviruses) and
    • Parasites (Giardia lamblia)
  • Autoimmune diseases (such as SLE and dermatomyositis) also occur in up to 20% of cases.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition Chapter 17, Pg 255

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with history of recurrent episodes of swelling of the submucosal tissue of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts from childhood. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates that her C1 inhibitor level is less than 6% of the reference value. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Hereditary angioedema is caused by deficient levels of C1 inhibitor. This reduces the ability to control activation of the classical pathway.
    • Autosomal-dominant inheritance
    • Gene locus: SERPING1(C1 inhibitor) on chromosome 11
    • Excessive spontaneous activation of classical complement pathway (especially C2) causing local inflammation of gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts.
    • Swelling of tracheal and bronchial passages can be life-threatening.
  • Nutrition-based immunodeficiencies are not does not presents with severely reduced levels of specific cell types or related molecules.
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is caused by a deficiency of CD59.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is caused by a deficiency of the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition Chapter 17, Pg 258

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, including pneumonia and skin abscesses. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly, but no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory findings show normal lymphocyte and neutrophil counts. A nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test is performed and comes back positive. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Chronic granulomatous disease is caused by defects in a degradative enzymes or other molecules involved in the oxidative burst.
  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome is caused by an inability to fuse lysosomes with phagosomes.
  • HIV/AIDS results from progressive destruction of CD4+ T cells. Although HIV can infect macrophages and dendritic cells, they remain capable of normal phagolysosome function.
  • Waldenstrüm's macroglobulinemia is caused by excessive production of IgM.

Chronic granulomatous disease

  • CGD is a genetic disease that has two forms:
    • X-linked form (more common, 70%): membrane component of phagocyte oxidase is defective.
    • Autosomal recessive form: cytoplasmic component of phagocyte oxidase is defective.
  • Inherited defects in the gene encoding NADP oxidase of phagocyte which breaks down hydrogen peroxide leads to decreased oxidative burst. This predisposes to
    • recurrent infections by catalase positive bacteria
    • inflammatory reactions that result in gingivitis, swollen lymph nodes, etc.

Diagnosis: Nitroblue tetrazolium reduction test (NBT) is positive.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition Chapter 17, Pg 258

questions.text: Loss of which molecules on the surface of the tumor cell would result in loss of susceptibility for killing?
questions.solution:
• The MHC class I molecules present the peptide antigen fragments from the tumor in a groove after it has moved to the surface of the tumor cell.
  • They present this peptide fragment to cytotoxic CD8 T cells.
  • The cytotoxic CD8 T cells recognize the MHC class I molecules on the cell surface and kill the tumor cell.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition Chapter 18, Pg 263

questions.text: Match the virulence factors of streptococci with its correct characteristic:
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 521

questions.text: A patient presented with a urinary tract infection had the following picture on Gram staining. Identify the correct organism from the photo causing the patient's symptoms:
questions.solution:
Enterococci produce various infections such as:

  • Urinary tract infections (cystitis, urethritis, pyelonephritis and prostatitis)
  • Bacteremia and mitral valve endocarditis (in intravenous drug abusers)
  • intra-abdominal, pelvic and soft tissue infections
  • Late-onset neonatal sepsis and meningitis
  • Infection on burn surface

They are gram-positive oval cocci arranged in pairs; cocci in a pair are arranged at an angle 10 each other (spectacle eyed appearance).

  • Non-motile cocci (except E. gallinarum and E.casseliflavus).
  • Blood agar: It produces non-hemolytic translucent colonies.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no:526

questions.text: A 5-year healthy girl presented as shown in the picture. She also had reduced appetite, seemed irritable, and complained of having a sore throat. On examination, the outermost layer of the skin sloughed off (positive Nikolsky's sign). Signs of early bilateral conjunctivitis were also present. At this stage, she did not have a fever. The mother consulted the emergency department. Identify the organism and its respective toxin causing such a clinical picture in this patient.
questions.solution:
The clinical picture described in the patient, including the presence of a positive Nikolsky's sign, early bilateral conjunctivitis, reduced appetite, and sore throat, suggests a condition known as Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS), which is caused by S. Aureus producing Epidermolytic Toxin (Exfoliatin).

Correct Answer: C) S. Aureus: Epidermolytic toxin

  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) is a serious skin condition typically caused by the exfoliatin (also called epidermolytic toxin) produced by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • The key clinical features of SSSS include skin sloughing (positive Nikolsky's sign), conjunctivitis, irritability, reduced appetite, and often a sore throat.
  • The causative toxin, exfoliatin, is an exotoxin produced by certain strains of S. aureus. This toxin targets desmoglein, a protein that helps bind skin cells together, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the dermis.
  • A) S. Aureus: Enterotoxin B is not the correct answer. Enterotoxin B is associated with food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus but does not cause SSSS.
  • B) S. Epidermidis: Epidermolytic toxin is not the correct answer. Staphylococcus epidermidis is not a typical causative agent of SSSS.
  • D) S. Aureus: TSST (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin) is not the correct answer. TSST is associated with toxic shock syndrome (TSS) and is not responsible for the clinical features described in this case.

In summary, the organism responsible for the clinical picture in this patient is Staphylococcus aureus producing Epidermolytic toxin, which leads to Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 512

questions.text: The following test is negative for all the organisms, except:
questions.solution:
• Aureus can be differentiated from CoNS (coagulase negative staphylococci) by various tests such as coagulase test and detection of protein A.
  • Most of the coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) are harmless commensals and less virulent than S. aureus, examples are: Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Staphylococcus lugdunensis and Staphylococcus schleiferi.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 516

questions.text:
A 6-year old child was brought to OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat and difficulty in swallowing. His past history is significant for not taking any vaccines for his age. On a clinical examination, the following picture was seen.

What is the mechanism of toxin released by causative organisms for the same?
questions.solution:
Virulence Factors (Diphtheria Toxin):

Diphtheria toxin (DT) is the primary virulence factor responsible for diphtheria.

  • The toxin is synthesized in the precursor form of molecular weight 58,700 kDa containing a polypeptide made up of 535 amino acids.
  • Toxin has two fragments; A (active) and B (binding) of molecular weight 121,500 and 37,200 kDa respectively.
  • Fragment B is the binding fragment which binds to the host cell receptors (such as epidermal growth factor) and helps in entry of fragment A.
  • Fragment A is the active fragment, gets internalized into the cell and then acts by the mechanism given below.

Mechanism of Diphtheria Toxin (DT)

  • Fragment A is the active fragment, which causes ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) -> leads to inhibition of EF-2 -> leads to inhibition of translation - step of protein synthesis.
  • Exotoxin A of pseudomonas has a similar mechanism like that of DT.

Factors Regulating Toxin Production

The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent on various factors.

  • Phage coded: DT is coded by a bacteriophage called beta-corynephage, carrying tox gene. C. diphtheriae remains toxigenic as long as the phages are present inside the bacilli (lysogenic conversion).
  • Iron concentration: the toxin production depends on optimum concentration of iron (0.1 mg per litre ). Higher levels of iron inhibit toxin synthesis by upregulating DT repressor genes in the bacterial chromosome.
  • DT repressor gene (DtxR): It is an iron-dependent negative regulator of DT production and iron uptake in C. diphtheriae.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 600

questions.text: You are posted in the dermatology department as an intern and a 56 year old female presented to dermatology OPD with complaints of hyperpigmented lesions in axilla. On wood's lamp examination a characteristic coral red fluorescence was seen. What would be the most likely causative organism responsible for a patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Minutissimum: It causes a localized infection of skin (axilla and groin), called 'erythrasma'. It is a lipophilic Corynebacterium, can be grown readily in media containing 20% fetal calf serum. On Wood's lamp examination, erythrasma lesion emits coral red color.

Tenuis: It has been associated with Trichomycosis axillaris, characterized by the formation of pigmented nodules, around axillary and pubic hair shafts.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 604

questions.text: An elderly female patient with thyroid carcinoma metastasized to the lungs became seriously ill following the initiation of chemotherapy. The patient was admitted with symptoms of generalized convulsion and an altered level of consciousness and was treated empirically with meropenem, amikacin and linezolid injection. Cultures of blood and cerebrospinal fluid revealed Listeria monocytogenes on day 5 post-admission. Along With immune compression, which of the following is a major risk factor for this infection?
questions.solution:
• Listeriosis is caused by \Listeria monocytogenes, which is a food-borne pathogen that can cause serious infections, particularly in neonates, pregnant women and elderly people. It is also a ubiquitous saprophyte and known to cause epizootic disease in birds and animals.
  • Listeriosis is common among extremes of age (neonate and old age).
  • Use of proton pump inhibitors increases the risk by reducing the gastric acid mediated killing of Listeria.
  • Other risk factors: Pregnant women and immunocompromised individuals are at higher risk.
  • Due to its ability to survive refrigeration (4°C), it is commonly found in stored foods especially aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk and cold salads.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 698.

choices.text: Prescribe ATT and advise him to begin with ART 8 weeks later
Prescribe ART and advise him to begin with ATT 8 weeks later
ATT is not recommended in HIV AIDS

questions.text: Rajesh is a 32 year old man who has been worried about his weight loss. He was 70kgs 6 months ago and currently weighs 58kg. He has also been experiencing bouts of diarrhea, episodes of fever in the evening and generalized fatigue. Upon repeated questioning he revealed having illicit relations and unprotected intercourse with his partner. Unfortunately, he tested positive for both HIV AIDS and TB. You explain to him that he will have to undergo treatment for both. He asks you if he can just take his medications together. What will you counsel?
questions.solution:
• The optimal timing to commence ART in HIV-infected patients with TB is relatively complex.
  • It must balance the risk of morbidity and mortality in very advanced HIV disease with the potential occurrence of additive toxicities, drug-drug interactions, and TB-associated immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).
  • The current World Health Organization guidelines recommend that ART should be started as soon as possible "within the first 8 weeks" of starting anti-tubercular treatment and within the first 2 weeks for patients who have CD4 cell counts less than 50 cells/mm3

Reference: https://aidsrestherapy.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12981-016-0106-y

questions.text: Ramesh, a young engineer presented to the ENT OPD with complaints of bilateral nasal obstruction. Suresh, who is his roommate, says that there is a foul smelling discharge from Ramesh's nose, which baffles him since he cannot smell anything. On external examination, the nose is hardened and has a 'woody feel', as shown in the image below. Anterior rhinoscopy shows excessive crusting in both nasal cavities. On removing the crusts, the ENT resident observes wide roomy cavities. Ramesh undergoes an RT-PCR test for COVID-19, which is negative. Based on this history, the doctor orders a biopsy, whose findings reveal 'Miculicz cells'. Which of the following bacteria would you expect to see in the specimen?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette, with features of granulomatous diseases of the nose points towards Rhinoscleroma,caused by Klebsiella Rhinoscleromatis. A patient will typically present in 3 stages-

Stage 1- Atrophic- showing typical features of atrophic rhinitis (merciful anosmia, excessive nasal crusting and nasal obstruction and wide roomy cavities.)

Stage 2- Granulomatous- characterised by woody nose/hebra nose.

Stage 3- Cicatricial- presenting as a Tapir shaped nose.

On HPE, characteristic Russel bodies(Plasma cell inclusions) and Mikulicz cells(phagocytized bacteria ) are seen.

Treatment for Rhinoscleroma includes Rifampicin/Tetracycline/Streptomycin/Ciprofloxacin for 6weeks+ Steroids to reduce fibrosis.

Klebsiella ozaenae causes Primary atrophic rhinitis, which does not cause external nasal deformities as in the question above.

Serratia Marcescens is a normal soil saprophyte releasing a non-diffusing red pigment called Prodigiosin, which causes nosocomial UTI and Pneumonia. Due to its red pigment, it leads to pseudohemoptysis.

Klebsiella oxytoca is also implicated in nosocomial infections.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 614.

questions.text: You are doing a presentation on Vibrio. You come across a species of vibrio which shows 'Kanagawa' phenomena and grows in a halophilic media of upto 8% salt solution. Which of the following vibrio species are you most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
• Parahemolyticus shows kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar.
  • It grows in upto 8% salt solution, shows swarming growth on blood agar.
  • It is known to cause invasive diarrhea.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 417

questions.text:
You are studying biochemical reactions of bacteria. You come across the following test where a suspension of the bacteria along with bile salts gives a string like formation. Which of the following biochemical reactions will this bacteria show?

i. Cholera red reaction
ii. Kanagawa phenomena
iii. Black colonies on Tinsdale media
iv. Yellow colonies on TCBS agar
v. School of fish appearance on wet mount
questions.solution:
• The above image depicts a string test, shown by vibrio cholerae.
  • A suspension of the bacteria, along with bile salts gives a positive test.
  • Along with this, vibrio also shows a positive nitrate reduction test.
  • On a wet mount, it gives a FISH IN STREAM appearance. It is a non-fastidious bacterium.
  • Transport media include autoclaved sea water and VR media.
  • Enrichment media includes alkaline peptone water and Monsur's taurocholate tellurite agar.
  • Selective media are TCBS, where V. cholerae show yellow colonies and Monsur's GTTA. They are late lactose fermenters.

Other options -

  • The Kanagawa phenomena is shown by V. parahaemolyticus.
  • Black colonies on tinsdale media are shown by C. diphtheria.
  • School of fish appearance is shown by H. ducreyi, while V. cholera shows fish in stream appearance.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number-414.

questions.text: A 17 year old patient presented with weakness and numbness in both lower limbs. He is unable to move his legs, has fasciculations and absent DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes). His temperature is 98.4° F, BP is 112/70. On asking history, patient says, 'I ate undercooked food 4 days ago, but I frequently do that and I am usually fine. However, 2 days ago, I had blood in my stool and I panicked. Will I be okay, doctor?' The doctor puts a peripheral demyelinating disease in his differential. Which microbiological organism is most likely associated with this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Gullain Barre Syndrome (GBS) following a Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  • C.jejuni is a microaerophilic, thermophilic gram-negative organism.
  • It causes bloody diarrhea, which is self-limiting in nature.
  • Transmission is by undercooked food/unpasteurized milk/untreated water.
  • Lab techniques used are:
  • Gram staining shows gull-wing shaped organism
  • Dark Ground Microscopy shows Darting motility
  • Skirrow's/Campy BAP media
  • C.jejuni can also act as a trigger for GBS, which causes ascending paralysis with LMN-like features (loss of reflexes/fasciculations).
  • GBS is usually an afebrile condition and self-limiting in nature.

Other Options:

A, B, C, D: They can also act as a trigger to GBS, but are not associated with bloody diarrhea.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 419

questions.text: As shown in figure a 7 year old child presented to pediatric OPD with a lesion and a swelling having a history of visiting a pet farm 1 week before. On examination the lesion is painless. From the swelling, smear was made and was positive under warthin starry silver nitrate staining. Identify the disease and its causative agent in this patient
questions.solution:
• The presenting symptoms of a painless papule and a regional lymphadenopathy with a history of visit to pet farm is suggestive of cat-scratch disease caused by bartonella henselae.
  • B. henselae:
  • It is transmitted by exposure to cats (by scratch or bite).
  • It is the agent of cat-scratch disease:

Characterized by typical features such as regional lymphadenopathy and painless papule at the site of cat scratch. Rarely, atypical features such as hepatitis, splenitis, and retinitis may be seen.

  • Bacillary angiomatosis: An angio-proliferative disorder, characterized by neovascular lesions involving skin and other organs
  • Bacillary peliosis: Angio-proliferative disorder involving liver and spleen.
  • Warthin-Starry silver nitrate staining and immunofluorescence staining can be used to detect B. henselae from lymph node smears.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 315

questions.text:
60-year-old white female presenting to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath. Symptoms began approximately 2 days before and had progressively worsened with no associated, aggravating, or relieving factors noted. She had similar symptoms approximately 1 year ago with an acute, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation requiring hospitalization.

A physical exam reveals:
Temperature 103.3° F
Heart rate 88 bpm
Respiratory rate 30
BP 104/54
O2 saturation 90% on room air

The chest X-ray appeared as follows:


On culture: large, opaque, irregular colonies with metallic sheen were found on Nutrient agar and on peptone water surface pellicle was seen. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in the above patient?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is notorious for causing infections at almost all sites; most common being lungs, skin and soft tissues.

Chronic respiratory tract infections: It occurs in patients with underlying conditions that cause airway damage such as cystic fibrosis, or bronchiectasis. These infections are usually caused by mucoid strains of Pseudomonas.

Peptone water: Pseudomonas forms uniform turbidity with a surface pellicle formation, due to more oxygen tension at the surface.

Nutrient agar: It produces large, opaque, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen (described as iridescence)

Pigments: Most strains produce diffusible pigments which are either blue-green (pyocyanin), or yellow-green (pyoverdine). Some strains are nonpigmented Mostly colonies of Pseudomonas have a characteristic sweet ether or alcohol-like fruity odor.

Selective media - cetrimide agar.

For Pseudomonas associated infections, think:



Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 643

questions.text:
A 36 year old male patient having multiple sex partners presented to your OPD with genital ulcers that are painful and bleeds on touch. On clinical examination, inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged and tender

What is the most likely diagnosis and its causative organism?
questions.solution:
Haemophilus ducreyi is an etiologic agent of chancroid (or soft chancre), a sexually transmitted infection (STI) characterized by: Painful genital ulceration that bleeds easily; no inflammation of the surrounding skin Enlarged, tender inguinal lymph nodes (bubo). Incubation period can range from 4-7 days. There is no immunity following the infection; however, hypersensitivity may develop.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 762

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number-311.

questions.text:
Identify the cause of urethritis in the above image:
A
B
C
D
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 765

choices.text: A 12-year-old with a dog bite experiencing hydrophobia
A patient with travel history to Africa presenting with fever and jaundice
A 7-year-old with coryza and Koplik's spots

questions.text: Inclusion bodies are aggregates of viral proteins or virions that confer altered F staining properties to host cells. You find the following inclusion body in a particular cell and are asked whether the given inclusions are intracytoplasmic, intranuclear, or both. Which of the following cases will show inclusion bodies at a similar site to the one you identified above?
questions.solution:
• The above image shows owl eye inclusions, seen in CMV infections.
  • These inclusions are both intracytoplasmic and intranuclear.
  • Another virus which shows both these inclusions is Measles, a member of Paramyxoviridae.
  • Koplik's spots are pathognomonic of measles infection and hence C is the best answer.

Other options

A- describes Rabies infection. Rabies infection shows Negri bodies, which are intracytoplasmic

B- describes yellow fever, caused by Flaviviridae. They show Cowdry A inclusion bodies called Torres bodies, which are intranuclear.

D- describes rotavirus infection, which belongs to family Reoviridae. They show perinuclear intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 89

questions.text:
Manjeet, a 6-year-old boy, presented with mild fever, lethargy and flu-like symptoms since past few days. His past history was suggestive of Sickle Cell Disease. His laboratory parameters were as follows:
RBC count- 3.5 million/microliter (Normal- 4.2 to 6.1 million)
WBC count- 2500/cubic mm
Platelets count- 70,000/cubic mm
Which of the following organism might be responsible?
questions.solution:
• Above given scenario with lab parameters is suggestive of Aplastic Crisis in a Sickle Cell disease patient triggered by Parvovirus infection.
  • Parvovirus is the only single stranded DNA virus, while all other DNA viruses are double stranded.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses, icosahedral in shape and non-enveloped.
  • Parvovirus is transmitted most commonly by respiratory route, followed by blood exchange and transplacental route.
  • Parvovirus infects red cell progenitors and is responsible for:

Fifth day disease/Erythema infectiosum - shows slapped cheek appearance


Others conditions associated with Parvovirus are:-

  1. Pure Red Cell Aplasia
  2. Non-immune Hydrops Fetalis
  3. Aplastic Crisis - seen in Sickle Cell Disease patients E. Polyathropathy in pregnant females

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 29-year-old truck driver, Paramjit, presented to Dermatology OPD with an itch rash growing on his torso, which is shown in photo below. On examination, his temperature was 100.4°F and BP was 120/80 along with generalized lymphadenopathy. On rapid test, it was suggestive for HIV positive. What is the causative organism for this?
questions.solution:
Above image is highly suggestive for Kaposi Sarcoma, caused by HHV8.

  • Kaposi Sarcoma is an AIDS-defining illness, in which a tumor grows in skin, lymph nodes, internal organs or mucous membranes as red/purple/brown patches.
  • HHV8 belongs to subfamily of Herpesvirus and infects B-cells.
  • It commonly infects immunocompromised individuals, causing
  1. Kaposi Sarcoma
  2. Primary Effusion Lymphoma
  3. Castleman Disease

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl came to Medicine OPD with complaints of headache, fever, pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly. A local quack prescribed her an antibiotic, following which she developed rashes. On taking proper history, her doctor also notes that her boyfriend is also suffering from similar symptoms. Which is the most likely cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
• The girl is most likely having Infectious Mononucleosis, caused by Ebstein-Barr Virus (EBV).
  • Infectious Mononucleosis (Kissing Disease) is spread by salivary contact.
  • Presentation includes headache, fever, pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Rashes following Ampicillin therapy is also seen.
  • Lab Diagnosis is done by Paul Bunnell test/ Monospot test by detecting heterophile antibodies against sheep RBCs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of the sudden appearance of a rash on her trunk that started 6 hours ago and subsequently spread to her extremities. Four days ago, she was taken to the emergency department because of a high fever and vomiting. She was treated with acetaminophen and discharged the next day. The fever persisted for several days and abated just prior to appearance of the rash. Physical examination shows a rose-colored, blanching, maculopapular rash, and postauricular lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Roseola infantum is a self-limited viral exanthem (usually due to HHV-6 and less commonly, HHV-7) that primarily affects infants and young children and is characterized by a high fever for 3-5 days that is immediately followed by a blanching, maculopapular, non-pruritic rash.
  • The rash initially appears on the trunk but may spread to the face and extremities.
  • It is commonly associated with cervical, postauricular, and/or occipital lymphadenopathy and may also cause febrile seizures.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with painful genital sores, malaise, and fever for 3 days. He is sexually active with 3 female partners. Examination shows tender lymphadenopathy in the left inguinal region and multiple, punched-out ulcers over the penile shaft and glans. Microscopic examination of a smear from the ulcer is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions on a smear of an ulcer or opened vesicle describe the Cowdry A inclusion bodies seen in infections by herpesviruses such as HSV-1, HSV-2, VZV, and CMV.
  • These intranuclear inclusions are formed during herpesvirus replication within the nucleus.
  • Another microscopic characteristic of herpesvirus infection is the formation of multinucleated giant cells as a result of the fusion of multiple infected cells (seen on Tzanck smear).
  • Other Options:
    • Bipolar-staining intracytoplasmic inclusions means Donovan bodies, seen in Granuloma Inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis
    • Basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions mean Reticulate bodies, seen in LGV infection caused by Chlamydia
    • Basophilic intranuclear inclusions are seen in Adenovirus infections

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes for annual pelvic examination and Pap smear. A photomicrograph of cervical cells from the Pap smear specimen is shown. Cells similar to the one indicated by the arrow are most likely to be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The cell indicated by the arrow is a dysplastic squamous epithelial cell with an enlarged, irregular nucleus and hyperchromasia.

These are features of koilocytes.

  • Koilocytes are pathognomonic of an infection with HPV.
  • Condylomata acuminata, like cervical dysplasia, are caused by an infection with HPV and can therefore present with koilocytes on histopathology.
  • Condylomata acuminata are typically associated with HPV strains 6 and 11.
  • Other manifestations of HPV infection include vulvar and vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia, as well as skin warts (verruca vulgaris) and plantar warts.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with ear pain. The patient states that this morning he had trouble moving one side of his face. Physical exam is notable for right-sided paralysis of the upper and lower portion of the patient's face. Following finding is noted in patient's ear canal. Identify this syndrome.
questions.solution:
Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by a Herpes Zoster infection which can affect CN VII (causing facial paralysis) and CN VIII (causing hearing changes).

Other symptoms include ear pain, a vesicular rash that extends into the ear canal, and altered face sensation.

Patients with classic symptoms and no other neurological sequelae can be treated with acyclovir.

The diagnosis can be further confirmed with a Tzanck prep and a viral culture which should not delay treatment.

Other Options:

  1. Moebius syndrome shows palsy of 6th and 7th cranial nerve
  2. Frey syndrome has gustatory sweating and flushing, following head and neck surgery
  3. Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome shows facial palsy + fissured tongue + cheilitis + facial edema

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized malaise, yellowish discoloration of the eyes, and pruritus on the back of his hands that worsens when exposed to sunlight for the past several months. He has not seen a physician in 15 years. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and mild jaundice. There is a purpuric rash with several small vesicles and hyperpigmented lesions on the dorsum of both hands. The causal pathogen of this patient's underlying condition was most likely acquired in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
• This patient's scleral icterus and jaundice should raise suspicion for liver disease.
  • His pruritic rash that worsens upon exposure to sunlight is suggestive of Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (PCT), a condition that is associated with hepatitis C virus infection.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page 485-86

questions.text: Shashikant, a 54-year old man presented with features of encephalitis. He bred pigs in his farm and was suspected to have been in contact with an infected pig. His throat & nasal swabs were collected for rtPCR test of Nipah virus. What is the reservoir for this virus?
questions.solution:
Nipah virus is a zoonotic Paramyxovirus.

  • Reservoir: Fruit bats(Flying fox)
  • Transmission: via infected pigs (NOT by body fluids)
  • Clinical Features: like Encephalitis
  • Risk Factors: animal husbandry, ecological changes
  • Biosafety: Level 4 pathogens

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 718

questions.text: A 17-year old boy presented with confusion and disorientation. He was failing in his school exams. Her mother noticed his reduced attention and poor memory. His mother states that he is normally a "bright student" and is in all honors classes. The patient was not vaccinated as a child and developed measles at age 6. Since then, he has been healthy. MRI of the brain is obtained, as shown in image. Within 3 days of hospital admission, the patient develops unilateral, slow-myoclonic jerks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a slowly progressive, neurodegenerative disorder caused by a persistent measles virus infection.

Most patients will have a history of measles at an early age with a latent period that can range from 6-15 years. Initial symptoms include memory loss and changes in behaviour/personality that progress to disturbances in motor function (e.g., myoclonic jerks, ataxia, paralysis, and seizures).

Brain imaging will show multiple white matter hyperintensities, scarring, and cerebral atrophy. The prognosis is poor with patients deteriorating to coma and/or death within 1-3 years of diagnosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 724, 760

questions.text: A 34-year old male died after being in a coma. Prior to coma, he showed bizarre behaviour, hydrophobia and aerophobia. On a PM examination of a brain section, the following image was observed. Identify the condition and given image.
questions.solution:
In Rabies, following an animal bite, there is an incubation period of 20-90 days. There are 3 phases:

  1. Short Prodromal Phase: for 2-10 days, nonspecific symptoms
  2. Acute Neurologic Phase: for 2-7 days, shows hyperexcitability, hydrophobia, aerophobia, autonomic dysfunction, paralysis
  3. Coma & Death

Negri bodies: intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies with basophilic inner granules. Most common sites are neurons of the hippocampus and cerebellum.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 720

questions.text: Microscopy of fungal agent reveals the following. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Image shows broad base budding (figure of. 8 appearance) in blastomyces
  • Blastomycosis (also known as North American blastomycosis or Gilchrist's disease or Chicago disease).
  • Paracoccidioidomycosis (also known as South American blastomycosis, Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease) it causes Lutz mycosis
  • Histoplasmosis is a systemic granulomatous disease caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum. The species name is a misnomer as it is not capsulated. It was first reported by Samuel Darling (1905), hence is also known as Darling's disease.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 413

Reference : Sastry 3rd ed pg 379 to 383.

Image reference -https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blastomycosis#/media/File:Blastomyces_dermatitidis_GMS.jpeg

questions.text: A farmer had a thorn prick injury following which he developed warty lesion. The biopsy of the lesion is shown below. Identify
questions.solution:
• Chromoblastomycosis refers to slow growing chronic subcutaneous lesions caused by group of dematiaceous or phaeoid fungi (i.e. darkly pigmented fungi) that produce a characteristic morphology called sclerotic body.
  • Sclerotic bodies: Histopathological appearance of these fungi is characterized by formation of brown thick walled round cells (5-12 μm size) with multiple internal transverse septa. They are also called Medlar bodies or muriform cells or golden-brown septate 'copper pennies'.

Reference : Sastry 3rd edition pg. 581.

questions.text: A patient presents to ENT clinic with following presentation. The culture of organism is done. What is the causative agent
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with the otoscopic image showing black-headed filamentous growth is suggestive of otomycosis by Aspergillus niger.
  • Irritation and itching are the most predominant symptoms of Aspergillus niger infection. Pain is predominant in Aspergillus flavus infection.
  • The fungal mass in otomycosis is likened to a wet blotting paper/wet newspaper appearance. The appearances of otomycosis on otoscopy and the causative organisms are:
    • Black-headed filamentous growth - Aspergillus niger infection
    • Green or brown - Aspergillus fumigatus infection
    • White and creamy deposits - Candida infection
  • Rhizopus oryzae is one of the causative agents of mucormycosis.
  • The common clinical form of this opportunistic infection is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM). It is rarely implicated in otomycosis.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 409

Reference: Textbook of Ear, Nose, Throat and Head and Neck Surgery: Clinical and Practical; 3rd edition by Hazarika Pg. 52

questions.text: A HIV positive female presents with an indurated ulcer over the tongue. Laboratory findings show growth in cornmeal agar at 20 degrees Celsius, microscopy showing hyphae and growth in human serum at 37-degree Celsius show budding yeasts The probable cause is:
questions.solution:
• The history of oral ulcer / oral thrush in an immunocompromised (HIV) patient suggests one of the opportunistic pathogens.
  • The pathogen was able to grow in cornmeal agar at 20°C and produced hyphae and produced budding yeast in human serum at 37°C which suggests the cultural characteristics of Candida albicans.
  • Other options provided- Histoplasmosis, Blastomycosis and Coccidioidomycosis are all Dimorphic fungi which cause systemic mycosis. They neither produce oral ulcers in HIV patients nor hyphae on cornmeal agar.

Reference: Sastry 3rd edition pg. 378, 379 chapter 38

questions.text: In order to diagnose one of parasitic infections, a laboratory reared and starved vector is fed to a patient suspected of having a disease. This type of diagnostic technique is used for diagnosis of
questions.solution:
Option A -Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of pathogen by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, it may have ingested.Not only parasites, it is also useful to diagnose many bacterial infections like Rickettsial infections and Lyme disease caused by Borrelia. Chagas disease is a parasitic infection caused by T.cruzi transmitted by reduviid bug. Traditionally used to diagnose Chagas disease, it was also used previously for diagnosis of Babesia and filariasis. However, with development of newer diagnostic techniques like molecular tests, it is now rarely used for other infections.


Option - B - Amoebiasis trophozoite and cyst are excreted in feces and not present in the blood of infected patients.

Option - C & D - though transmitted by vectors and presence of parasites in blood, there are many other comparatively easier techniques available for diagnosis of malaria and leishmania than cumbersome Xenodiagnosis.

Reference : Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -8

questions.text: Match following parasites with their mode of infection.
questions.solution:
Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba which is present in freshwater lakes and reservoirs. Infection is acquired when a patient takes bath in infected water. Parasite enters by penetrating nasal mucosa.

Entamoeba histolytica is an amoeba and the infection is acquired through ingestion of contaminated food or water.

Ancylostoma duodenale is a nematode in which infective filariform larvae are present in soil. When a person walks barefoot on faecally contaminated soil, larvae enter the body through skin penetration.

Wuchereria bancrofti is a nematode in which infection acquired through bite of infected mosquito-species of Culex like C.fatigans or C.quinquefasciatus.

Reference : Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -4
